newsitem.title: USA: U.S. mortgage-backeds slide in active trade.
newsitem.headline: U.S. mortgage-backeds slide in active trade.

text.p: U.S. mortgage-backed securities traded lower Thursday afternoon, but yield spreads narrowed to U.S. Treasuries most of the day, traders said.
As Treasuries slipped on a number of technical and fundamental factors, market participants found decent bargains in mortgages, traders said.
"We're seeing an uptick in mortgage banker selling, but we're seeing mortgage buying on dips," said one.
He said eventually buyers will tire themselves out.
Meanwhile, however, traders snapped up deals where found, they said.
"We've been doing some buying today," said one head trader at a New York firm. "We still think in this apparent trading range ... mortgages still have some value."
The trader said he observed several small-size bid lists exchanging hands.
"We had a couple of little ones. Nothing really all that major -- its actually been three yards and a cloud of dust today," he said.
By late afternoon Thursday, Ginnie Mae 30-year 7.5 percent paper was down 12/32 at 99-14/32, yielding 108 basis points over the 10-year Treasury note.
Comparable Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac issues were 12/32 lower as well, at 99-12/32 and 99-17/32, respectively.
The 10-year note was off 10/32 at 99-17/32 to yield 6.56 percent.
Looking forward, traders said it will take some time before pass-throughs shake out of their range.
"They definitely shake out on the way up ... it is on the way down that they are stubborn," said one.
PSA The Bond Market Trade Association recommended an early 1400 EST/1900 GMT close on Friday and a full close on Monday in observance of Martin Luther King's birthday.
